results.title: As a matter of fact: a film about abortion
results.creator_credit: Robyn Dryen, Susan Lambert, Creative Development Branch of Australian Film Commission, Womens Film Fund and Women's Health Resources Foundation
results.brief_description: A documentary about a feminist run abortion clinic. Counselling is shown to be an important part of the procedure, which is carried out using local anaesthetic and the vacuum aspiration method. We follow one woman through the termination of her pregnancy, and other women tell why they chose to have an abortion. The film ends with an animated section on the struggle for free, legalised abortion in Australia and information on what to do and where to go if you are pregnant.

results.title: William Delafield Cook interviewed by Deborah Hart...
results.creator_credit: Queensland Art Gallery, Deborah Hart and Ian Stocks
results.brief_description: This video provides a unique opportunity to explore the ideas and works of the Australian born artist William Delafield Cook. Produced in conjunction with the artist’s Retrospective at the Art Gallery of New South Wales, it covers the stylistic development of his art from the 1950’s to the present day. Delafield Cook lives and works both in England and Australia. Widely travelled, his art embodies an exceptionally diverse interest in art history, photography and films.

results.title: Women in the workforce
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth De Rome and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: The claim that sex is destiny is thought by many to be ludicrous, yet in practice, is this actually the case? The express purpose of this film is to promote discussion of and around the conscious and unconscious barriers women have to face daily in the workforce.

results.title: An Australian Summer
results.brief_description: A gentle comedy exploring, on a humorous and compassionate level, the shifting relationships within an Australian family over two decades, 1960-1980. The complexities of a family relationship where love as a binding force is tested by disappointment, are evocatively portrayed with a deft mixture of humour and poignancy.

results.title: MIMA Yearbook. Vol. 1
results.brief_description: Volume one of a three volume set, this video compilation of excerpts from Australian film and video art covers the period from 1962-1980, and is a unique and tantalising entry into the non-mainstream history of Australian film and video.

results.title: Australian tourism [advertisement]
results.brief_description: Developed by Mojo MDA for the Australian Tourism Commission this advertisement was part of the ‘come and say g’day’ campaign and features Paul Hogan in a range of locations across Australia. It also uses a range of Australian slang expressions including a play on the famous expression ‘put another prawn on the barbie’.

results.title: Expectant spaces
results.brief_description: A commissioned Public Imaging project by Melbourne cinematographer, Ben Speth. His extraordinary, meditative work manifests as a mysterious visual documentation of volume, light and time in deserted urban spaces. A sense of expectancy emerges through his still, ghostly and enigmatic images of spaces of waiting or anticipation - hospital emergency rooms, bus shelters, classrooms, dental waiting rooms, car parks.

results.title: Bush Mechanics: Episode 4: The Rainmakers
results.creator_credit: Francis Jupurrula Kelly, David Batty, Jennifer McMahon, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Warlpiri Media and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The ‘Bush Mechanics’ comprise a group of five young Warlpiri men from Yuendumu in the Northern Territory who can face any challenge when it comes to fixing cars, no matter what condition the car may be in! They will use the bush as a resource for spare parts and do whatever it takes to keep a car on the road. Their inventiveness, wonderfully offbeat humour and crazy antics, provide an insight into both contemporary and traditional Aboriginal culture. In the style of a road movie, the ‘Bush Mechanics’ series follows the men across the central desert, through their many mechanical mishaps, challenges and exploits. In Episode 4, these involve covering thousands of kilometres across the west to Broome to search for pearl shells for the rainmaker. The Bush Mechanics are: Simeon Jupurrula Ross, Steven Jupurrula Morton, Errol Jupurrula Nelson, Junior Jupurrula Wilson and Randall Jupurrula Wilson. Also features Jack Jakamurra Ross, and Francis Jupurrula Kelly. In English and Warlpiri with English subtitles.

results.title: The Door
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Anne Pratten, Jo-Anne McGowan and Josie Keys
results.brief_description: A bedroom door becomes the focus of a teenage girl’s battle with her insensitive stepfather to reclaim the simpler relationship she remembers sharing with her mother. Stars Barry Otto and Penne Hackforth-Jones. Original format 16mm.
